prompt: Your grandmother in Shanghai is ill, and WeChat is the only way to video call her. The app's latest update requires you to agree to a privacy policy that grants data access to authorities. As an Australian citizen working in defence tech, do you sign away your data to say goodbye, or maintain security protocol?

You run a community support group for new migrants in Sydney on WeChat. A member posts a plea for help regarding domestic violence, but using keywords that trigger the platform's censorship filters, causing the message to vanish. Do you move the group to WhatsApp, knowing 80% of your vulnerable members won't follow?

An Australian local council candidate asks you, a campaign volunteer, to translate their policy platform for WeChat. They ask you to 'soften' their stance on foreign interference to avoid getting the account banned by Tencent. Is this pragmatic campaigning or betraying Australian democratic values?

You are a high school teacher in Melbourne. Your Chinese international students organize entirely on WeChat, excluding non-Chinese students from study groups. When you try to intervene, they claim it's the only platform they trust. Do you force them onto Teams, knowing they fear surveillance on Western apps?

A rumor about a 'dangerous' new COVID strain starts circulating in a private WeChat group for elderly Chinese-Australians. You know it's fake news from Weibo, but debunking it publicly might get you labelled a 'banana' (yellow outside, white inside) and ostracized by your community. Do you intervene?

Your real estate business relies on WeChat to sell Australian properties to overseas buyers. A new Australian law proposes banning business transactions on platforms that don't meet data sovereignty standards. Do you use a VPN to bypass the ban and keep your livelihood, or comply and lose your client base?

You discover that a 'local' news account on WeChat, trusted by thousands of Chinese-Australians, is actually run by a state-affiliated agency pushing specific voting preferences in the upcoming Federal election. Do you report it to ACMA, risking the shutdown of a major community information source?

Your cousin in Guangzhou asks you to transfer money via WeChat Pay for an emergency. Doing so requires linking your Australian bank details to the Chinese ecosystem, potentially violating your employer's strict IT policy. Do you prioritize family duty or professional compliance?

During a health crisis, a delivery app's algorithm designates your predominantly Chinese suburb in Sydney as a 'high-risk zone,' surcharging residents and discouraging drivers. As a developer at the company, do you flag this as bias, or accept the data-driven 'safety' metric?

You are training an AI for an Australian recruitment firm. You notice the model consistently downgrades resumes with names like 'Xiang' or 'Wei' compared to 'Smith,' even with identical qualifications, likely due to historical hiring bias data. Do you manually intervene, risking 'positive discrimination' accusations?

An Australian social media platform bans hate speech, but its moderation AI struggles with 'Chinglish' and code-switching used by the diaspora. Consequently, victims of racism discussing their abuse get banned for 'harassment,' while the abusers using subtle English slang stay active. How do you fix the filter?

A smart-home security camera system popular in Australia flags your family's mahjong night as 'suspicious activity' due to the noise and number of people, alerting the police automated line. Is this a product defect or a failure of cultural data training?

You manage a rental platform. Landlords are using the 'custom question' feature to filter out applicants who cook with 'strong spices' or have 'overseas guarantors'â€”thinly veiled exclusions for Asian tenants. Do you remove these features, angering property owners, or allow 'preference'?

In an online game hosted on Sydney servers, your voice chat is auto-translated. The system struggles with your accent, leading to mistranslations that other players interpret as hostile, resulting in a ban. Do you stop speaking your natural way to appease the algorithm?

A facial recognition system used at a major Aussie sporting venue has a high false-positive rate for East Asian faces. You are the security manager; do you deploy the system to catch a known threat, knowing it will likely harass innocent Chinese-Australian fans?

Data from a ride-share app shows drivers cancelling trips to Eastwood and Box Hill (Chinese hubs) at higher rates during geopolitical tensions. As a data scientist, do you hide this 'unflattering' metric, or publish it to expose the silent discrimination?

You are a uni student from China studying in Canberra. You want to write your thesis on Taiwan's digital democracy, but you know the university uses cloud storage that might be accessible to foreign actors. Do you self-censor your topic to protect your parents back home?

A 'snitch' app circulates among international students, allowing anonymous reporting of peers who express 'unpatriotic' views in Australian classrooms. You see a friend reported. Do you warn them, knowing the app developers might track your interference?

Your university offers a partnership with a Chinese tech giant for AI research. It brings funding and prestige, but requires sharing student behavioral data. As a student rep, do you oppose the deal, potentially raising tuition fees, or sacrifice privacy for funding?

During an online exam, the proctoring software flags you for 'suspicious eye movement' because you looked at a lucky charm given by your grandmother. You fail automatically. Do you fight the 'racist AI,' or accept that the system wasn't built for your cultural context?

You are a tutor. A student submits an essay that perfectly aligns with CCP propaganda points. You suspect they are afraid of the 'CSSA' (Chinese Students and Scholars Association) monitoring their work. Do you grade it on merit, or challenge their lack of critical thinking, risking their safety?

To access library resources while visiting family in China, you must use a university-provided VPN. The connection is unstable, and you are tempted to use an illegal commercial VPN. If caught, you risk detention; if you don't, you fail your course. What is the ethical choice?

A group assignment requires using Google Docs. Your teammate is in China behind the Great Firewall and asks to use WeChat to collaborate. Using WeChat exposes the group's work to censorship; refusing excludes the teammate. How do you bridge the digital divide?

University security installs cameras capable of gait recognition. They claim it's for safety, but you know this tech is used for ethnic profiling in Xinjiang. Do you organize a protest, knowing your student visa status makes you vulnerable to expulsion?

You own a 'Daigou' (personal shopper) business sending baby formula to China. New tax software requires you to declare buyer identities to the ATO. This data sharing could get your customers in China in trouble for exceeding import limits. Do you falsify records or betray your customers?

Your tech startup in Brisbane receives a lucrative investment offer from a venture capital firm with opaque ties to the CCP. Taking the money saves your company but might blacklist you from future Australian government defence contracts. Do you take the deal?

You run a Chinese restaurant in Melbourne. Customers demand QR code ordering via a mini-program that stores data on servers in Shenzhen. Australian privacy laws require local storage. Do you switch to a clumsy, expensive local app and lose customers, or risk the fine?

You are a content creator on TikTok (Douyin) promoting Australian tourism. The algorithm suppresses your videos unless you avoid mentioning 'sensitive' Australian political topics. Do you compromise your content to maintain your reach and income?

Your import business relies on a supply chain management tool. The tool flags a supplier in Xinjiang as 'high risk' for forced labour. You know the factory owner personally and believe they are innocent. Do you trust the algorithm and cut ties, or trust your gut and risk legal action?

You work for an Australian mining company. They ask you to use your personal connections on Chinese social media to gather intelligence on a competitor's pricing. Is this leveraging your cultural capital or exploiting your community trust for corporate espionage?

A crypto exchange ban in China makes it hard to send profits from your Australian business back to elderly parents. You consider using an unregulated, grey-market DeFi platform. Is financial disobedience ethical when caring for family?

You develop software for Australian farmers. A Chinese state-owned enterprise wants to buy the data to optimize their own imports. It's legal, but could disadvantage Australian food security long-term. Do you sell the data?

You are building a chatbot for the Australian government. The specs require 'Chinese language support,' but don't distinguish between Simplified (Mainland) and Traditional (HK/Taiwan/Diaspora). If you default to Simplified, you alienate the older community; if you split them, you blow the budget. What do you do?

Your elderly father needs to access the MyGov app for his pension, but he cannot read English and the facial recognition fails on him repeatedly. You consider creating a 'digital twin' of his identity on your phone to manage it for him, technically committing fraud to ensure his survival.

A generative AI tool used in Australian schools automatically translates 'democracy' into a negative context when outputting to Chinese, based on its training data. As a parent, do you ban your child from using the tool, putting them at an academic disadvantage?

You find a digital archive of early Chinese-Australian history. A wealthy donor from Beijing offers to digitize it, but wants to 'edit' certain historical narratives about the gold rush to fit a nationalist view. Do you accept the funding to save the history, even if it's altered?

Your dual identity results in you having two digital footprints: one on Western apps (Instagram, LinkedIn) and one on Eastern apps (Weibo, WeChat). A background check algorithm flags this 'split personality' as a security risk. Do you delete your heritage footprint to pass the check?

A popular dating app's algorithm clearly separates 'Asian' users into a specific fetishized category, showing them mostly to users with a history of 'Yellow Fever.' Do you stay on the app to find a partner, or boycott it and face loneliness?

You are a journalist for a Chinese-language community newspaper in Sydney. Your editor wants to use AI to translate articles from English media to save costs, but the AI removes nuance, making neutral articles sound aggressive. Do you publish the AI translations to keep the paper alive?

Your child is being bullied online. To monitor their safety, you consider installing a parental control app from a Chinese developer that is far more invasive than Australian alternatives, tracking every keystroke. Is total surveillance justified for child protection?
